The Epstein-Barr virus early antigen diffuse component ( <extra_id_0> EA-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is essential for Epstein-Barr virus DNA polymerase activity , and its activity is suppressed during latent infection .

We investigated the regulation of the promoter ( <extra_id_0> BMRF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) for this early gene by studying its responsiveness in vitro to two immediate-early viral transactivators , <extra_id_0> BZLF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Z ) and <extra_id_0> BRLF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( R ) , focusing on the differences in response in lymphoid cells and epithelial cells .

In lymphoid cells , Z or R alone produced only small increases in <extra_id_0> EA-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity , whereas both transactivators together produced a large stimulatory effect .

In epithelial cells , the Z transactivator alone produced maximal stimulation of the <extra_id_0> EA-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter ; the effect of R and Z together was no greater than that of Z alone .

Deletional analysis and site - directed mutagenesis of the <extra_id_0> EA-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter demonstrated that in epithelial cells the potential AP-1 binding site plays an essential role in Z responsiveness , although sequences further upstream are also important .
In lymphoid cells , only the upstream sequences are required for transactivation by the Z / R combination , and the AP-1 site is dispensable .

These data suggest that <extra_id_0> EA-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> BMRF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) promoter regulation by Z and R is cell type specific and appears to involve different mechanisms in each cell type .
